revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox military unit | unit_name = 10th Special Forces Group (Airborne) | image = [[File:USA - 10th Special Forces Flash.svg|150px]] | caption = 10th Special Forces Group (Airborne) beret flash | dates = 19 June 1952 – present | country = {{flag|United States of America}} | allegiance= | branch= {{army|United States}} | type= [[Special Operations Forces]] | role= | size= | command_structure=[[File:US Army Special Forces SSI.png|20px]] [[Special Forces (United States Army)|United States Army Special Forces]] | garrison=[[Fort Carson]] | garrison_label= | equipment= | equipment_label= | nickname= | patron= | motto= The Best | colors= | colors_label= | march= | mascot= | battles=[[Stay-behind|Cold War]]
[[Congo Crisis|Congo]]
[[Operation Gothic Serpent|Somalia]]
[[Gulf War]]
'''[[War on Terror]]''' *[[Operation Enduring Freedom]] *[[Iraq War]] *[[Operation Freedom's Sentinel]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Maryland-Soldier-Killed-By-Roadside-Bomb-In-Afghanistan-396091811.html|title=Maryland Soldier Killed by Roadside Bomb in Afghanistan|publisher=nbcwashington|date=5 October 2016}} | anniversaries= | decorations= | battle_honours= | current_commander= | current_commander_label= | ceremonial_chief= | ceremonial_chief_label= | colonel_of_the_regiment= | colonel_of_the_regiment_label= | notable_commanders= [[Colonel]] [[Aaron Bank]] | identification_symbol=[[File:US Army 10th SFG(A) Flash.png|150px]] | identification_symbol_label=[[Parachutist Badge (United_States)#Airborne background trimming|unit oval]] }} The '''10th Special Forces Group (Airborne)''' ('''10th SFG(A)''' or '''10th Group''') is an active duty [[United States Army Special Forces]] (SF) Group. The 10th Group is responsible for operations within the [[United States European Command|EUCOM]] [[area of responsibility]], as part of the Special Operations Command, Europe ([[SOCEUR]]).{{cite web|title=10th Special Forces Group (Airborne)|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/army/10sfg.htm|accessdate=10 May 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080514175712/http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/army/10sfg.htm| archivedate= 14 May 2008 }} 10th Group has also been involved in parts of [[Africa]] and the [[Middle East]]. In 2009, as part of a new [[United States Special Operations Command|SOCOM]] directive, the group is now also responsible for operations within the [[United States Africa Command|AFRICOM]] area of responsibility.{{cite web|title=SOCom directive announces major changes | Army Times | armytimes.com |url=http://www.armytimes.com/article/20090827/NEWS/908270331/SOCom-directive-announces-major-changes |work= |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6HsSJalef?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.armytimes.com%2Farticle%2F20090827%2FNEWS%2F908270331%2FSOCom-directive-announces-major-changes |archivedate=5 July 2013 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2013-07-01 |df=dmy }} 10th SFG(A) was formed on 19 June 1952, at [[Fort Bragg, North Carolina|Fort Bragg]], North Carolina, under the command of Colonel [[Aaron Bank]].{{cite web|title=10th SFG Official History |url=http://www.soc.mil/SF/history.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=10 May 2008|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090920094659/http://www.soc.mil/SF/history.pdf |archivedate=20 September 2009 |deadurl=yes}} The group was split in 1953, with one half being sent to Germany, while the other half remained at Fort Bragg to form the core of the [[7th Special Forces Group (United States)|77th Special Forces Group]] (redesignated as the 7th SFG in 1960). In 1968, the majority of the unit transferred to [[Fort Devens]], [[Massachusetts]], with the exception of 1st Battalion, which remained in Germany. Between 1994 and 1995, 10th SFG(A) moved to [[Fort Carson]], [[Colorado]], which remains its current home. 10th Group began training with [[unconventional warfare]] groups from friendly countries in the 1960s, beginning with [[NATO]] allies. The group has also trained various components of the militaries of several [[Middle Eastern]] countries, including [[Lebanon]], [[Jordan]], [[Yemen]], [[Iran]], as well as [[Kurdish people|Kurdish]] tribesmen. Units of the 10th SFG(A) have participated in [[humanitarian]] missions to the [[Republic of the Congo (Léopoldville)|Congo]], [[Somalia]], and [[Rwanda]]. 10th SFG(A) was deployed to [[Saudi Arabia]] in 1991 during the [[Gulf War|First Persian Gulf War]]. The 10th SFG has been heavily involved in the [[War on Terrorism]], deploying to [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[North Africa]], [[Afghanistan]], and consistently to [[Iraq War|Iraq]]. ==History== ===1950s=== [[File:SpecialForces Badge.svg|thumb|right|The Regimental Insignia of the Special Forces.]] In 1950, the [[Lodge-Philbin Act|Lodge Act]] was passed, which provided for the recruiting of foreign nationals into the United States military. It was originally planned that half of the members of the Special Forces would be native Europeans. Many of the initial members of the 10th SFG(A) were Lodge Act recruits, who were strenuously anti-Communist.{{Cite book | last = Southworth | first = Samuel A. | title = U.S. Special Forces | publisher=Da Capo Press | year = 2002 | isbn =978-0-306-81165-4 | postscript = }} Among the more notable of these men was MAJ. [[Larry Thorne]], a former Finnish Army soldier who was awarded the [[Mannerheim Cross]] during World War II. By the end of June 1952, the group had 122 officers and men assigned. Many had been [[Office of Strategic Services|OSS]], [[United States Army Rangers|Ranger]], and [[Airborne forces|Airborne]] troopers during [[World War II]]. The group's mission was to conduct partisan warfare behind Soviet lines in the event of a Soviet invasion of Europe.{{Cite book | last = Pushies | first = Fred J. | author2-link = | title = U.S. Army Special Forces | publisher=Zenith Press | year = 2001 | isbn =978-0-7603-0862-2 | postscript = }} On 10 November 1953, the 10th SFG(A) was split in half, with one half deployed to [[Bad Tölz]] and [[Lenggries]] in [[West Germany]], and the other remaining in Fort Bragg to become the 77th Special Forces Group (which in 1960 became the [[7th Special Forces Group]]). The green beret was authorized for wear by Col. William E. Ekman, the group commander, in 1954, and it became group policy. By 1955, every soldier in the unit wore a green beret as part of the uniform. However, the Department of the Army (DA) did not recognize the beret as headgear. The DA banned the wear of the beret, but it was later restored by President [[John F. Kennedy|Kennedy]], a major champion of the Special Forces.{{Cite book | last = Moore | first = Robin | title = The Green Berets: The Amazing Story of the U.S. Army's Elite Special Forces Unit | publisher=Skyhorse Publishing, Inc. | year = 2007 | isbn =978-1-60239-017-1 | postscript = }} The 10th Group encountered publicity for the first time in 1955 when the ''[[New York Times]]'' published two articles about the unit, describing them as a "liberation" force designed to fight behind enemy lines. Pictures showed soldiers of the group wearing their berets, with their faces blacked out to conceal their identities. ===1960s=== The A-teams of 10th Group began exchange training with unconventional forces in friendly countries, including United Kingdom, Germany, France, Norway, Spain, Italy, and Greece. This training taught 10th Group soldiers how to subsist on native food, and built valuable rapport with the host nation forces.{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} In the summer of 1960, 10th Group deployed to the newly independent [[Republic of the Congo (Léopoldville)|Congo]], to evacuate Americans and Europeans to [[Kinshasa|Leopoldville]], where there would be a larger evacuation, led by Belgian paratroopers. The group evacuated 239 civilians without a single casualty in only nine days. As the United States became increasingly involved in Vietnam, counter-insurgency became the primary focus of the Special Forces, rather than the traditional unconventional warfare. While the 10th SFG(A) was never deployed to Vietnam, the soldiers and officers assigned to it did rotate through the country as part of different special forces groups.{{Cite book | last = Hagerman | first = Bart | title = U.S.A. Airborne: 50th Anniversary | publisher=Turner Publishing Company | year = 1997 | isbn =978-0-938021-90-2 | postscript = }} [[File:Vietnam era organization chart for Special Forces groups.GIF|thumb|300px| left| Special Forces Group organization in the Vietnam Era]] During the Vietnam War, detachments of 10th Group began training Middle Eastern special warfare forces. In Jordan, B Detachment established the first airborne school, and King Hussein attended the graduation parachute jump. In 1963, Company C of 10th Group trained 350 officers and [[Non-commissioned officer|NCOs]] of a guerrilla force fighting the socialist government in Yemen. Detachments also traveled to Iran to train the Iranian Special Forces, along with Kurdish tribesmen in the mountains of Iran. A-Teams also trained Turkish and [[Special Services Group|Pakistani special forces]]. In 1968, 10th Group, minus the 1st Battalion, was transferred to [[Fort Devens]], Massachusetts. 1st Battalion remained in Bad Tölz, Germany.{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} ===1970s – 1980s=== Following the military cuts after the end of the Vietnam War, operational deployments decreased in both number and frequency. However 10th Group still deployed frequently to Europe to train with [[NATO]] allies. From 11 May 1983 to 25 October 1985, 10th Group deployed 17 Mobile Training Teams (MTT) to Lebanon, to support the Lebanese Army. The teams created a training program for over 5,000 officers, NCOs, and soldiers, which included basic training sites, unit training, unit combined arms live fire training, and urban live fire training. The [[Lebanese Civil War#Syrian intervention|entry of the Syrian Army]] into Lebanon ended the program prematurely. An MTT from the 1st Battalion, Bad Tolz, Germany deployed to [[Operation Restore Hope|Somalia]] for four months to conduct disaster relief operations in June 1985. In 1986, a detachment of 10th Group trained the nucleus of the Nigerian Airborne forces. The 10th Group was the leading force behind the development of the [[M25 Sniper Rifle|M25]] [[sniper rifle]] in the late 1980s, at Fort Devens. The rifle is an improvement on the previous [[M21 Sniper Weapon System|M21 sniper rifle]], itself a modification of the [[M14 rifle|M14]] semi-automatic rifle. ===1990s – 2000s=== [[File:10th SFG in Mali.jpg|thumb|left|A soldier from 10th Group training soldiers from Mali]] [[File:10th SFG parachute Mali.jpg|thumb|right|Training parachute jump in Mali]] Following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, an MTT deployed to Kuwait to train the [[Saudi Arabian National Guard]]. During the [[Battle of Khafji]], the MTT accompanied the SANG forces into battle, coordinated troop movements, called in airstrikes, and assisted with artillery fire support. Other elements of 10th Group deployed to southeast Turkey in support of operations Desert Shield/Desert Storm. The ''[[Boston Herald]]'' reported: "The 10th Special Forces Group's penchant for secrecy is so exacting the base publicist didn't know the unit had gone to war until they were on their way home from Operation Desert Storm."http://www.soc.mil/SF/history.pdf {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009025542/http://www.soc.mil/SF/history.pdf |date=9 October 2007 }} Following the end of the Gulf War, [[Saddam Hussein]] turned his attention to Iraq's Kurdish minority, causing over half of a million Kurds to flee into the mountains on the Turkish-Iraqi border. Under the leadership of Colonel William Tangney, all three battalions of 10th Group were deployed to the area for [[Operation Provide Comfort]], a UN humanitarian effort. 10th Group coordinated the ground relief effort, and was credited by [[John Galvin (soldier)|General Galvin]], the [[EUCOM]] commander, as having "saved half a million Kurds from extinction". During [[Operation Restore Hope]], 10th Group deployed a Coalition Support Team to support the 1st Belgian Para-Commando Battalion. In addition to supporting the Para-Commando unit, the CST assisted the [[10th Mountain Division (United States)|10th Mountain Division]], and provided security for meetings with Somali leaders. Following the ethnic conflict in Rwanda, 10th Group deployed to [[Entebbe]] airfield, Uganda. The group assisted the displaced persons in returning to their homes. On 2 September 1994, 2nd Battalion, 10th SFG(A) transferred to [[Fort Carson]], [[Colorado]], followed by 3rd Battalion on 20 July 1995. The group headquarters moved to Fort Carson on 15 September 1995, ending a 27-year presence in Massachusetts. [[File:US Special Forces soldiers from 3rd Battalion, 10th SF Group (Airborne), conduct shoot-house training at Fort Carson Colo Sept 30 2009.jpg|left|thumb|Special Forces soldiers from 3rd Battalion, 10th Special Forces Group (Airborne), conduct shoot-house training at [[Fort Carson]] in September 2009]] Affiliated for operations with Special Operations Command – [[United States European Command|Europe]], 10th Group is continuing to conduct [[Joint Combined Exchange Training]] and FID/anti-terrorist operations as part of [[Operation Enduring Freedom – Trans Sahara]].{{cite news|title=U.S. Pushes Anti-Terrorism in Africa|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/25/AR2005072501801.html|accessdate=10 May 2008 | work=The Washington Post | date=26 July 2005}} Such activities have included training the [[Military of Mali]] and the [[Military of Mauritania]].{{cite web|title=Special Forces Support Pan Sahel Initiative in Africa |url=http://www.defenselink.mil/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=27112|accessdate=10 May 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080519145436/http://www.defenselink.mil/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=27112| archivedate= 19 May 2008 }} The 1st and 3rd Battalions of 10th Group also participated in training in Senegal in 2006, along with the [[352d Special Operations Group]] of the [[US Air Force]].{{cite web|title=352nd SOG wraps up JCET to Trans-Sahara, Africa |url=http://www.mildenhall.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123024337|accessdate=11 May 2008}} 10th SFG(A) has also deployed numerous times in support of [[Operation Enduring Freedom]] and [[Operation Iraqi Freedom]], but mostly to Iraq, since the start of the [[War on Terrorism]]. 10th SFG(A) and [[CIA]]'s [[Special Activities Division]] Paramilitary Officers were the first to enter Iraq prior to the [[2003 invasion of Iraq|invasion]]. They organized the Kurdish [[Peshmerga]] to defeat [[Ansar al-Islam]], an ally of [[al-Qa'ida]], for control of a territory in Northeastern Iraq that was completely under Ansar al-Islam's control. This battle, one of the most important engagements for Special Forces since Vietnam, led to the elimination of a substantial number of terrorists and the discovery of a chemical weapons facility at Sargat (the only facility of its type discovered in the Iraq war). Three [[Silver Star]]s and six [[Bronze Star]]s for valor were conferred for this engagement.[http://www.usnews.com/usnews/news/articles/041018/18excerpt.htm A firefight in the mountains: Operation Viking Hammer was one for the record books – US News and World Report] These terrorists would have been part of the subsequent insurgency had they not been eliminated during this battle, which could be called the Tora Bora of Iraq. While several key leaders escaped into Iran, it was a sound defeat for al-Qaeda and Ansar al-Islam.Operation Hotel California: The Covert War Inside Iraq, Sam Faddis and Mike Tucker, Publisher: Lyons Press, The Pub. Date: October 2008,{{ISBN|978-1-59921-366-8}} The Americans then led the Peshmerga against Saddam's northern Army. This effort kept Saddam's forces, including 13 Armored Divisions, in the north and denied them the ability to redeploy to contest the invasion force coming from the south. This effort likely saved the lives of hundreds, if not thousands, of coalition service members.Plan of Attack, Bob Woodward, 2004 ==Subordinate units== * Headquarters and Headquarters Company * Group Support Battalion * 1st Battalion – stationed at [[Panzer Kaserne]] [[Böblingen]]-[[Sindelfingen]] of [[Regierungsbezirk|Region]] [[Stuttgart, Germany]] http://www.soc.mil/USASFC/Groups/10th/1stBNnewcomers.html * 2nd Battalion * 3rd Battalion * 4th Battalion ==Notable officers and soldiers== * [[Colonel]] [[Aaron Bank]] – The "Father" of Army Special Forces and first commanding officer of the 10th Special Forces Group (Airborne). * [[Major (United States)|Major]] [[Lauri Törni|Larry Thorne]] – Finnish soldier who fought the Soviet Army during the [[Winter War]], immigrated to the United States after World War II and joined the US Army under the [[Lodge-Philbin Act]]. 10th Group honors him yearly by presenting the Larry Thorne Award to the best [[Special Forces (United States Army)#ODA|Operational Detachment-Alpha]] in the command.{{cite web|title=The Ideal Green Beret|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-230160265.html|author=States New Service|accessdate=January 16, 2014|publisher=[[HighBeam Research]] |date=30 June 2010}} In an episode of [[The Big Picture (TV series)|''The Big Picture'']] released in 1962 and composed of footage filmed in 1959, Thorne is shown as a lieutenant with the 10th Special Forces Group in a United States Army.[http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=6a6_1306565247 "Phantom Fighters. USA Special Forces Training." (TV-448) 1962] via [[LiveLeak]]. * [[Master Sergeant#United States|Master Sergeant]] [[Gary Gordon]] – Went on to service with [[Delta Force]], awarded the [[Medal of Honor]] posthumously for his actions during the [[Battle of Mogadishu (1993)|Battle of Mogadishu]]. * Major [[Tommy Sowers]]: [[Duke University]] graduate, [[Iraq War]] veteran. Graduated top of his class from the Special Forces Qualification Course. Completed a PhD at the [[London School of Economics]]. Served as Assistant Secretary of [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs|Veterans Affairs]] for Public and Intergovernmental Affairs (August 2012-April 2014). ==References== {{Portal|United States Army|Special Operations}} {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.defenselink.mil/PhotoEssays/PhotoEssayImage.aspx?id=9891&name=Joint%20Airborne%20Operation%20in%20Colorado Defense.gov: Photo Essay Image]: Department of Defense photo gallery of 10th Special Forces Group (Airborne) conducting airborne operations in Colorado {{US Army SFG}} [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1952]] [[Category:Special forces groups of the United States Army|Special Forces 010]]
